body.text: AI chatbots have become increasingly common. How much do you know about how they actually work?

With no prior knowledge, explore what goes into building an AI chatbot (like ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek). From choosing the type of data it's trained on to the tone it responds in, see how the technology really works, and how your decisions can impact its outcomes. Learn what labor and resources are required behind the scenes, and what capabilities, limitations, and risks they introduce.
Complex chatbots, or "conversational agents" such as ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek, are often powered by large language models (LLMs).

A "language model" is a piece of software that is trained to predict language sequences and generate text responses. A mobile keyboard's autocomplete function, like the example below, is a language model.

body.text: STAGE 1: TRAINING

To build a language model, you need training data, or large bodies of text a model finds patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet is a large source of text already written by other people, like forums, books, or research papers. To start building your chatbot, select a data source below:

The first thing youâ€™ll need to build a language model is training data, or large bodies of text that a language model looks for patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet provides a large source of text data, like social media sites, blogs, digital books, or research papers. To start building your chatbot, select a data source below:
Going from massive data to a working model requires extensive power and resources, often at computing hubs called data centers.
This process is expensive and environmentally costly, using up large amounts of energy.
The model can estimate the probability of a character, word, or sequence of words occurring in text based on how commonly it occurred in your data source, and generates new text accordingly.
Pick a sentence from the examples below, and see what word is most likely to come next:

autocompleteOptions.sentence: At the beach, I played with my ____

body.text: By acquiring information and learning from text patterns in the data, a language model can seem to ramble about a topic.
For example, if you ask: What is your first name?
Based on what typically occurs next in empty online forms, it may respond with: What is your last name?
This is where post-training and fine-tuning come in, to turn the model from sounding like a random text generator to a realistic chatbot.
STAGE 2: POST-TRAINING
This process includes high-quality instructions and human feedback, like yours.

You will see a question with two answer options generated by the model, and pick what you think is the better answer. Real chatbots similarly learn patterns from thousands of choices made by humans, often workers hired for this task. What counts as 'better' depends on who's deciding.

body.text: You're almost done building your chatbot! In this final step, craft its "personality" by deciding how it responds to questionsâ€”more like a friend, a teacher, or a boss. But remember, regardless of how friendly or relatable it soundsâ€”which can make it easy to forget you're talking to a machineâ€”the underlying technology will still do the same thing:
Make statistical predictions about what text should come next.
Stage 3: Deployment
Time to try out your chatbot! It will generate text based on your previous decisions, like your choice of training data or level of friendliness.
Now that you know how this technology is built, reflect on what kinds of questions are appropriate to ask a language model. Select as many questions as you want, then click 'Next'.

body.text: AI chatbots have become increasingly common. How much do you know about how they actually work?

With no prior knowledge, explore what goes into building an AI chatbot (like ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek). From choosing the type of data it's trained on to the tone it responds in, see how the technology really works, and how your decisions can impact its outcomes. Learn what labor and resources are required behind the scenes, and what capabilities, limitations, and risks they introduce.
Complex chatbots, or "conversational agents" such as ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek, are often powered by large language models (LLMs).

A "language model" is a piece of software that is trained to predict language sequences and generate text responses. A mobile keyboard's autocomplete function, like the example below, is a language model.

body.text: STAGE 1: TRAINING

To build a language model, you need training data, or large bodies of text a model finds patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet is a large source of text already written by other people, like forums, books, or research papers. To start building your chatbot, select a data source below:

The first thing youâ€™ll need to build a language model is training data, or large bodies of text that a language model looks for patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet provides a large source of text data, like social media sites, blogs, digital books, or research papers. To start building your chatbot, select a data source below:
Going from massive data to a working model requires extensive power and resources, often at computing hubs called data centers.
This process is expensive and environmentally costly, using up large amounts of energy.
The model can estimate the probability of a character, word, or sequence of words occurring in text based on how commonly it occurred in your data source, and generates new text accordingly.
Pick a sentence from the examples below, and see what word is most likely to come next:

autocompleteOptions.sentence: At the beach, I played with my ____

body.text: By acquiring information and learning from text patterns in the data, a language model can seem to ramble about a topic.
For example, if you ask: What is your first name?
Based on what typically occurs next in empty online forms, it may respond with: What is your last name?
This is where post-training and fine-tuning come in, to turn the model from sounding like a random text generator to a realistic chatbot.
STAGE 2: POST-TRAINING
This process includes high-quality instructions and human feedback, like yours.

You will see a question with two answer options generated by the model, and pick what you think is the better answer. Real chatbots similarly learn patterns from thousands of choices made by humans, often workers hired for this task. What counts as 'better' depends on who's deciding.
